Title: Life in a Cold Climate: The Adaptation of Cereals to New Environments and the Establishment of Agriculture in Europe

This project aims to investigate the critical role of environmental adaptation in the spread of agriculture and its adoption as the primary subsistence strategy in Europe. Despite significant advances in understanding the human dimension of domestication, the environmental pressures that shaped the adaptation of crops to European ecosystems remain poorly understood. By integrating population genomics, ecological modeling, ancient DNA sequencing, and computational methods, we will identify the genetic loci in barley and wheat genomes that were under selection during the introduction of agriculture to Europe. We will associate these selected loci with ecogeographical variables, date the adaptation periods, and synthesize the environmental adaptations with dating evidence for agricultural spread. Our approach will also correlate these findings with demographic data and analyze archaeobotanical databases to provide a comprehensive understanding of the adaptation process. This project will correct the current imbalance between human and environmental dimensions in domestication studies, providing new insights into Neolithic population dynamics and crop productivity. By elucidating the critical role of environmental adaptation in the establishment of agriculture in Europe, this project will have significant implications for our understanding of the origins of modern European societies.

Title: Life in a Cold Climate: The Adaptation of Cereals to New Environments and the Establishment of Agriculture in Europe

This project aims to investigate the critical role of environmental adaptation in the spread and adoption of agriculture in Europe during the Neolithic period. By integrating cutting-edge methods in population genomics, ecological modeling, and ancient DNA sequencing, we will identify the genetic adaptations of barley and wheat to new environments and correlate them with ecogeographical variables. Our approach will also employ computer methods to establish the temporal order of these adaptations. The expected outputs include the identification of selected loci in cereal genomes, the association of these loci with environmental factors, and the dating of adaptation periods. We will further synthesize these findings with archaeological evidence for the spread of agriculture and correlate them with demographic data. Our project addresses a significant imbalance in current research, which has focused primarily on the human dimension of domestication, neglecting the critical role of environmental pressures. By providing new insights into the interplay between ecological adaptation and the establishment of agriculture in Europe, this project will shed light on Neolithic population dynamics, crop productivity, and the long-term sustainability of agricultural systems.

Our outputs will include a synthesis of environmental adaptations with dating evidence for agricultural spread, correlation with demographic data, and an analysis of archaeobotanical databases. By studying the adaptation of barley and wheat to new environments, this project will correct the imbalance between human and environmental dimensions in domestication research, providing valuable insights into Neolithic population dynamics and crop productivity. Our findings will have significant implications for our understanding of the introduction of agriculture into Europe and the development of more resilient and sustainable agricultural systems.
